subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in 4.8, how can I avoid specifying classes 	in @Suite.SuiteClasses
msgSnippet: B책rd, It s a run-around, but you currently have to use nested suites, like this: To: @RunWith(ClasspathSuite.class) public class AllTests { }
messageBody:
B책rd,

It's a run-around, but you currently have to use nested suites, like this:

To:
@RunWith(ClasspathSuite.class)
public class AllTests {
}

@RunWith(Categories.class)
@...(SlowTests.class)
@...({AllTests.class})
public class OnlySlowTests {
}

David Saff

On Mon, Dec 14, 2009 at 3:19 AM, B책rd Lind <bard.lind@...> wrote:
> Hi. Georg and David.
>
> Thanks for your replies.
> The classpath-suite might be a good solution. Unfortunately it does not seem
> to support Categories, thoug.
>
> I changed my Suite from
>
> @RunWith(Categories.class)
> @...(SlowTests.class)
> @...({AppTest.class})
> public class SlowTestSuite {
> }
>
> To:
> @RunWith(ClasspathSuite.class)
> @...(SlowTests.class)
> public class SlowTestSuite {
> }
>
> Then my "FastTests" are also run, not only the SlowTests.
>
> David, do you think you can implement Categories in your filtering aka
> @ClassnameFilters?
>
> Thanks
> B책rd
